Comment: Good one
I consider that it's maybe too easy, try to spicy it up. Although it might be good for big noobies, it's kind of a brezze for most.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved in python 81 characters, 4 minutes. Great contribution!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le choix du mode taille de code est trÃ¨s intÃ©ressant et permet d'optimiser l'emploi des fonctions nÃ©cessaires Ã  la rÃ©solution du problÃ¨me.

As complex numbers are integrated in Python (with "j" instead of "i"), the solution can be expressed simply by:
z=eval(input().replace('i','j'))
print("{:.1f} {:.1f} {:.1f}".format(z.real, z.imag, abs(z)))

This may be a bit too simple for Python users compared to other languages that don't have that native complex type.

I like it.

My JS solution:

[_,a,b]=/(.*)((\+|\-)(.*))i/.exec(readline())
print(...[+a,+b,(a*a+b*b)**.5].map(x=>x.toFixed(1)))

New solution:
[a,b]=readline().split(/[+i]/)
print(...[+a,+b,(a*a+b*b)**.5].map(x=>x.toFixed(1)))

Changed Title, Description, Input, and Output a little bit. Hope it's ok.

I strongly suggest removing "(A Lot Of Thank You To SPDene ðŸ™)".
And you should consider this puzzle for Reverse mode too.

Overall pretty good. Change it from "WIP" to "Ready" and you'll have "approved" from me.

Suggested Output:
Change
Show out the a and b and magnitude of Z in 1 decimal place
to
Show a, b, and the magnitude of Z, to 1 decimal place

In all your tests and validators, a >= 0 and b>=0
To save people having to code for negatives (especially for Shortest mode), I would include these as constraints.
Alternatively, include tests which have negative a and b.

Your "longer!" validator seems a bit unfair:
5455645646 is greater than 2^31, and may require a different datatype in some languages; the largest value in any of the visible test cases is 1543.45

This is my first contribute
so I'm sorry if my work was failed
and sorry for my grammar :v

thank for suggest 
but i don't wanna change from shortest to reverse mode
bc, it will be easy in reverse mode

Cool trick with print(...[ ]). Combines well with formatting via map function.
But the first line is kinda ugly and the '-' case is outed by Constraints.
`[a,b]=readline().split(/[+i]/)` would work.
in ruby complex numbers use "i", so it would be even simpler
You are right lopidav, I considered that a and b could be negative

Well, you don't need to change it to reverse, it can be both in reverse and shortest.

But on the second thought, I don't like it very much in reverse since it may be too hard to figure out that the third output is magnitude. But with the addition of some hinting tests, it may be good.

You can also add it to the fastest, but I would recommend putting a definition of the magnitude in the statement since it's not that popular term. 

Also, you may want to add a test case of a=0.


Right now I don't like approving this solely because of the test names. It's not a big deal but if you don't mind changing "This is my first contribute" and "idk what should put here" to something that shows more confidence and describes the cases more I would appreciate it if you do. You can still use humor and be expressive of course, I'm not asking to be more serious.

Whatever you decide to do, please ping me afterwards by replying to this comment.

ah ic
And yes I know that is bad joke on the test's name
so I have already changed it.
really ty for suggest :)
